revision_history.draft:
# The Man in the Kitchen

He keeps the living room window
sealed against whatever left outside —
a small plastic baggie
taped over the lower pane,
the upper one kept clean enough
for him to read the newspapers through.

March turns into April
and there is no event he misses.

The drapes, though. The drapes
hang heavy in their tracks,
cotton and polyester holding
their pleats against a draft
that has not yet crossed the threshold.

His coffee grows cold.
The cup darkens a ring
on the table's oak,
and under that — circles
going soft with dust,
the slow forgetting of places
he might wipe before it set.

Somewhere in the neighborhood
a sprinkler wakes at five,
water finding the lawns
with its pale, mechanical touch,
but he hears it only when it stops,
that hold-between-rings
of sound that leaves the air
flat as a lake without wind.

The dust on the light fixture
has not yet thinned enough
to catch his eye. The boots
by the door have gone
the color of March —
gummid soles leaching into uppers,
caked with whatever
he dragged across ice.
They know more about spring
than he does.

He peels an orange at the counter.
The bright segments separate
against the green cloth he uses
for this, and each one curls
toward his thumb — a small
act of opening nobody asked for.

Outside, the birch tree
has already dropped its flowers.
They lie in the grass like something
the ground swallowed without chewing,
still damp, still white,
and no one comes to gather them.

He cuts the orange into wedges.
One falls. He picks it up.
It is warm inside. The radio
plays talk shows he disagrees with.
The drain holds a glass
halfway through its life —
he washed it before, in another life,
set it down, and now
the water has forgotten
what it was invited to do.

Spring did not come for him.
It sat on the sill
and stopped breathing. He
continued arranging his lemons
by density, by sourness,
a small architecture no one
will walk into.

The dust on the ceiling fan
has not moved. The boots
have softened into their new color.
He will wear them out to the store,
return them back across the sidewalk,
not once but twice,
and each time the season
between his steps stays
the way it was — a thing
he carried without noticing,
a door he opened
with his mouth, then closed.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The final six lines are the strongest passage in this poem, and they earn their weight because everything preceding them built toward it with genuine restraint:

> "a thing / he carried without noticing,
> a door he opened
> with his mouth, then closed."

That closing image — spring as something ingested, not encountered — is precise, strange, and the character's obliviousness becomes physical. The body moving through winter and into boots that soften "into their new color" also works: it makes perception (or lack thereof) visible.

The orange-peeling sequence from lines 43–52 has real texture. Each detail — segments curling toward his thumb, the radio playing talk shows he disagrees with, the glass halfway through its life — accumulates without overstating. The domestic objects *become* the poem's subject rather than decorating it.

The dust on the ceiling fan not moving / boots having softened — that parallel earns its place because both lines are doing similar work: showing awareness absent where expected.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché and dead phrasing (throughout):**
"flat as a lake without wind," "a small architecture no one will walk into," "set it down, and now / the water has forgotten / what it was invited to do." These are the poem's own avoidance of its own brief — decorative language where plainness should be. The lake line especially reaches for atmosphere that belongs to a different poem. Direction: strip every simile. If the thing can't be said in one or two concrete images, cut it.

**Overcrowded domestic detail (lines 13–26):**
The drapes, the coffee ring, the table dust, the boots — this is accumulation without selection. Each object gets a line or two and then sits inert. The direction on the brief asked for "minimal" objects carrying weight. Right now there are too many carrying no weight at all. Direction: choose three domestic details that *distinguish* this character's perception from everyone else's. Cut the rest.

**Tonal inconsistency / editorializing (lines 27–36):**
"The drapes, though." "Somewhere in the neighborhood" — these lines step outside the character into a narrator offering information or commentary. The mechanical sprinkler waking at five is a nice image, but "he hears it only when it stops" adds an interpretive frame ("hold-between-rings / of sound that leaves the air / flat as a lake") that belongs to the poet, not the character. Direction: let the drapes just hang heavy — don't name the reading of them.

**Line 39 ("still damp, still white"):**
Redundancy without emphasis. "Still" appears twice in three lines elsewhere (line 48), which reads as a habit rather than deliberate compression. Direction: choose one

He keeps the living room window
sealed against whatever left outside —
a small plastic baggie
taped over the lower pane,
the upper one clean enough
for him to read the newspapers through.

March turns into April
and there is no event he misses.

The cup darkens a ring
on the table's oak,
and under that — circles
going soft with dust,
the slow forgetting of places
he might wipe before it set.

Somewhere in the neighborhood

water finding the lawns
with its pale, mechanical touch,
but he hears it only when it stops,
that hold-between-rings
of sound that leaves the air
flat as a lake without wind.

The birch tree has already dropped its flowers.
They lie in the grass like something
the ground swallowed without chewing,
still damp, still white.

He peels an orange at the counter.
The bright segments separate
against the green cloth he uses
for this, and each one curls
toward his thumb — a small
act of opening nobody asked for.

Outside, the window stays closed.
Inside, the radio
plays talk shows he disagrees with.
The drain holds a glass
halfway through its life —
he washed it before, in another life,
set it down, and now
the water has forgotten
what it was invited to do.

He cuts the orange into wedges.
One falls. He picks it up.

The dust on the ceiling fan
has not moved. The boots
have softened into their new color.
He will wear them out to the store,
return them back across the sidewalk,

and each time the season
between his steps stays

a door he opened
with his mouth, then closed.

final_poem:
He keeps the living room window
sealed against whatever left outside —
a small plastic baggie
taped over the lower pane,
the upper one clean enough
for him to read the newspapers through.

March turns into April
and there is no event he misses.

The cup darkens a ring
on the table's oak,
and under that — circles
going soft with dust,
the slow forgetting of places
he might wipe before it set.

Somewhere in the neighborhood

water finding the lawns
with its pale, mechanical touch,
but he hears it only when it stops,
that hold-between-rings
of sound that leaves the air
flat as a lake without wind.

The birch tree has already dropped its flowers.
They lie in the grass like something
the ground swallowed without chewing,
still damp, still white.

He peels an orange at the counter.
The bright segments separate
against the green cloth he uses
for this, and each one curls
toward his thumb — a small
act of opening nobody asked for.

Outside, the window stays closed.
Inside, the radio
plays talk shows he disagrees with.
The drain holds a glass

He cuts the orange into wedges.

The dust on the ceiling fan

He will wear them out to the store,
